well, all you really have to do is to copy the kernel to '/boot/', install the modules, and then add a new section to '/boot/grub/menu.lst'. There are tutorials/HOWTOs on doing this. What is the problem in doing it?
well, the kernel would be 'arch/i386/boot/bzImage' wherever you put the sources.
typically you would do like: 'cp -p arch/i386/boot/bzImage /boot/vmlinuz-mine', and similarly 'cp -p System.map /boot/System.map-mine'. And then create a new entry in the GRUB config.
it gets a bit more complicated if your newly build kernel needs an 'initrd' image, because then you need to build it.
you could spare yourself some complications if you built the kernel with 'kpackage', which builds an installable '.deb' for you.
